gravity_system: Roof Trusses, Loadbearing Walls, Rubble Foundation
other_materials: Blown-in Insulation, Wood Shingles, Steel Sheet Roofing
key_elements: Rubble Foundation, Decorative Bump-Out, Sewage Tank, Drainage Tile, Egress Windows
overall_building_description: The building's structural framework is characterized by the integration of existing and new construction elements, ensuring compliance with modern standards while preserving the integrity of the original structure. The existing roof, composed of steel sheet roofing and wood shingles, is maintained in a structurally sound condition, supported by 2x4 wood vestibule scissor trusses. The installation of new blown-in insulation with a minimum R-value of 75 enhances thermal performance, addressing energy efficiency requirements. The existing 24-inch thick laterally unsupported rubble foundation is preserved, demonstrating adequate bearing capacity and lateral stability for the building's load path. The foundation's condition is verified to be in good standing, ensuring a reliable base for the superstructure. The floor system incorporates 5/8-inch tongue and groove floor plywood, glued and screwed, supported by 2x8 floor joists at 16 inches on center, complete with midspan blocking. This configuration provides composite action and deflection criteria compliance, enhancing the floor's load-bearing capacity. The 2x10 rim board is securely fastened to the existing 16-inch brick wall using 1/2-inch diameter turn-in concrete lags, embedded a minimum of 6 inches and staggered at 24 inches on center, ensuring shear transfer and lateral stability. The new floor joists extend past the wall to accommodate a decorative bump-out, adding architectural interest while maintaining structural integrity. The building's spatial relationships are articulated through detailed section cuts, such as the longitudinal and transverse sections, which reveal the integration of multiple levels and the continuity of load paths. The transverse section, oriented looking east, highlights the attic, main floor, and basement, providing insights into the vertical load transfer mechanisms. The attic, previously uninsulated, is upgraded with R75 blown-in insulation, enhancing the building's thermal envelope. The main floor, featuring a kitchen/dining/living area of 900.31 square feet, is supported by existing 2x12 wood floor joists at 16 inches on center, ensuring adequate load distribution. The building's compliance with the Ontario Building Code (OBC) is evident in the specifications for new egress windows and railing heights, ensuring safety and accessibility. The integration of a new 4-inch drainage tile around the perimeter, draining into a new sump pit, addresses site-specific conditions, mitigating potential water infiltration issues. The assembly sequence prioritizes the installation of structural elements, followed by the integration of mechanical and architectural components, ensuring a cohesive construction process. The project adheres to stringent fabrication requirements, with precise welding symbols and bolt specifications guiding the assembly of structural connections. The use of engineering jargon, such as load path, moment connection, and diaphragm action, underscores the technical rigor applied throughout the design and construction phases. The building's transformation from an existing church to a residential use is facilitated by strategic structural modifications, ensuring compliance with local bylaws and performance requirements. The project exemplifies the seamless integration of new and existing elements, achieving a balance between preservation and modernization.
